moves.1. d4 d5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. e3 e6 4. Bd3: At this point, white is playing passive. I am not aware that he's playing Colle's system. Therefore I decide to transpose into a Queen's gambit.
moves.4... c5 5. c3: White's response seemed strange (I didn't realise it's Colle's opening). NC6 would have been the continuation of QGD, but I wasn't sure of what white is playing. Nd7 seemed better because Nc3 doesn't seem to be coming.
moves.5... Nbd7 6. Nbd2:
At this point, I looked up the GameDB and realised that this is a Colle's system. A quick wikipedia look (did I cheat?) showed that white's plan is to push E5, and attack kingside possibly with a bishop sacrifice to pick h7.
My counter play was to deny E5 (wikipedia said that the system is inflexible) - and keep a somewhat symmetrical position to attack h2 and g2 with my bishops.
moves.6... Bd6 7. O-O O-O 8. Re1 b6: Preparing to get bishop in line to X-ray g2.
moves.9. dxc5: This move is crucial for black. BxC5 will allow e4, dxe3 and Nxe4. Either I have to give up the dark squared bishop (which is very strong as pawns are on light squares) or move it to a passive e7.
moves.9... Nxc5 10. Bc2: Tables are turning - now white is hiding it's good (light squared) bishop.
moves.11. b4 Nce4: Best square for the knight! This blocks the centre - denying access to h7. It is defended thrice.
moves.13. Nd2: White wants to push f3 to push pressure on e4 (I guess).
moves.13... f5: Fortifying e4 - continuing with the plan to deny E4 access.
moves.14. Nxe4: I think this was a mistake - now pawns will lock down the centre and white is too passive.
moves.14... fxe4: Now black has a rook lift available as well.
moves.15. a4:
This was a crucial mistake. While pushed queenside because the original plan of colle's sacrifice has been blocked.
But tables are turned - black can get dark squared bishop, queen and rook to attack the king, which is defenceless.
moves.16. Kxh2 Qh4+ 17. Kg1 Qxf2+ 18. Kh2 Rf6: And the took lift - white is lost now.
moves.19. Kh3 Rg6:
This was a mistake. Rh6 was better. Rh6, Qh5, Rxh5, Kg4, Qh4#. Black missed this line and game will drag a bit with Qg4, Rxg4, Kxg4, Qxe1 and so on.
But white resigned as it's going to Q,R,B against just 1 rook (or bishop). Black queen can clean up almost the entire back rank which is completely disharmonious.
